intro: Gilia longiflora var. laxiflora, commonly known as the lax-flowered gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often hairy, while its stems are erect and branched. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
